IS OCCUPIED
New Physics Laboratory To Be
Dedicated Next Spring
TO BE NAMED MON DA Y
1929

Building Program
Completed

Is

Hopkins' latest addition to the
field of science—her new Physics
Building—was opened to the students of the University on Mon(lay. The formal dedication of the
new building which is as yet unnamed will take place some time
during the Spring of 1930. The
Opening of this building caps the end
of one of the most prosperous
years of Hopkins' existence.
Other Hopkins Improvements

During the past year Hopkins
has taken such gigantic strides forward, that it now is one of the best
balanced scientific schools in the
world. 1929 has seen the formal
dedication of the new Fellowship
Plan, and the dedication of the
Chair of Chemical Education. Hopkins has acquired one of the best
medical libraries in the world, in
her new Welch Memorial Medical
Library. The Wilmer Ophthalmological Institute has been formally
dedicated. A new student-activities
center in Levering Hall has been
established. Few universities of our
size in this country can boast of as
beautiful a student-activities center
as Levering Hall. The Carroll
Mansion is being remodeled into a
Museum of Colonial Activities.
Plans have been formulated for a
building opposite Carroll Mansion
to house this country's FIRST Institute of Laws. Even at the present time students are devoying much
effort for the erection of a new
Cage or gymnasium at Homewood Field. Even with all these
Plans to beautify our campus, the
officers of the University have not
completed their work.
Building Modern

The erection of the new Physics
Building marks the completion of
the Homewood Plan of the University for 1929. This new structure, built at the cost of $565,000,
is still uncompleted. It contains four
lecture rooms, and twelve classrooms, as well as several laboratories, research rooms and offices.
The building will be immediately occupied by the Mathematics and the
Physics departments. In a statement
to the NEWS-LETTER reporter, Dr.
Hubbard, Professor of Physics
Stated:"At the present time the new
Physics Building is the MOST
modern and best-designed physics
building in this country, however,
I. do not expect it to hold that position for many years, for colleges
are jealous of honors, and some
Other university may soon erect a
structure to rival ours in modernity."
To Be Named By Trustees

The name for the building will
Probably be chosen on October 28
at the next meeting of the Board
of Trustee's of the University. Dean
Berry stated that the structure
would probably be named for one of
the foremost physicists that the
World has ever known. He declined
to state whether or not that individual had attended this University.
The top floor of the new hall
Will be known as the Museum of
Physics and will contain the original
instruments used by famous Hopkins scientists in their struggles to
advance science to the position it
now enjoys. Among the celebrated

JAYS CRUSHED
BY SYRACUSE
Syracuse Rolls Up 85-6 Score
Over Jays
NIGHT CONTEST
Gridiron Lighted By 44 1,000Watt Bulbs
Last Saturday night the Blue
Jays were crushingly defeated by
the strong Syracuse team, which
seemingly had no trouble in running
rough shod over their southern opponents and rolling up a tremendously large score. The game was
started at 8 P. B., and the field,
which was lighted by the strong
rays of forty-four 1,000-watt bulbs,
was as light as day. The previous
Saturday, Syracuse had fought the
strong western eleven from the University of Nebraska, the game being very close and both elevens
fighting like tigers. It was only
through sheer brute strength and
very hard fighting, that Nebraska
wa sable to triumph over their opponents, winning by the score of 13
to 6. This year Syracuse is playing
the majority of her games at night
under the powerful arc lights and
on her own gridiron.
New Practice

The practice of playing football
games at night is a new and experimental one. It is thought that
larger crowds can be drawn to the
stadiums for these games by having
them in the evenings. It is also
felt that many of those people who
have to work Saturday afternoons
and are necessairily kept from attending afternoon contests, would
be interested in night games and
would attend them.
New Experience

This game was the first one that
Hopkins had ever played at night
and naturally it was a novel experience for them. At first they were
not used to the glaring lights, but
they were soon able to acclimate
themselves to this new situation and
to eliminate the confusion into
which they had been thrown at the
beginning of the game.
Hopkins Outclassed

From the very start, it was easy
to see that Hopkins was outclassed
in every shape and form by the
strong, well-experienced Syracuse
eleven. Last year Syracuse had a
very powerful team and defeated
Hopkins by a large margin and the
team this year is made up of most
of the old regulars from last season. Naturally these husky men,
who had seen battle in more than
one season, were more than a match
for the crippled Jay team.
Hopkins Alert

Although the Jays were thoroughly outclassed, they nevertheless
showed the old Hopkins fighting
spirit and were alert and always on
the look-out for any breaks that
might come their way. They were
rewarded, in the first part of the
last quarter by a little streak of
luck, which netted them a touchdown.
Jays Score

The Orange team had started
another march down the field and
were sure of scoring. A long forward pass was attempted and Merriken, Hopkins' right halfback intercepted it and made a beautiful
run of 47 yards to place the ball
on Syracuse's 10-yard line. After
a forward pass had been grounded,
the ball was given to Bledsoe, who
carried it over for Hopkins' only
tally. The try for the extra point
failed and the Jays were forced to
content themselves with the one
touchdown.

OPKINS students are appreciative. One organization and one
achievement of that organization have especially received their
share of that appreciative attitude. We speak of Levering Hall, the
property of the University branch of the Y. M. C. A.
Levering Hall has opened wide its doors to every one affiliated with
Hopkins. It is appreciated. But the appreciation of the student seems
to be slowly but surely fading.
Since the opening of college, Hopkins students have made themselves
at home. It is undoubtedly proper and to be expected that this "at
home" attitude exists, providing no one passes the limit defined by that
comprehensive phrase. But some have passed.

H

Within the last several days we have noticed several tendencies
indicative of this condition. The combination radio and phonograph
does not operate. This seemed to be expected by many who have been
heard to say, "It did last pretty long, though." When the defect has
been repaired let us be content to enjoy it as an instrument and not
a toy.
The broken radio is not the only indication of the attitude we have
mentioned. Coats, hats, and books are to be seen nearly any hour of
the day, strewn over chair backs, tables, or windowsills. Lockers have
been distributed for the disposition of our garments and texts during
the hours of classes. During functions, we may check our coats at the
room set aside for that purpose. Thoughtlessly tossed articles do not
add to the appearance of the large lobby in Levering Hall.
Ashes are flicked to the floor, although ash trays have been furnished
in abundance throughout the several rooms. Even if a tray is not
within reach, a few steps would bring it so. Cigarette ashes are not
allowed to remain on the floor, due to excellent janitor service; but
certainly the sight of a student carelessly dropping ashes or the remnants of his "smoke" on the floor is not conducive to an appreciative
attitude in others.
Loud talk is becoming increasingly noticeable. One of the conditions
most deplored by authorities was the speech and loudness of those who
frequented the second floor of the Barn. Levering Hall is as much at
the disposal of the young ladies of the University as at the disposal
. of the male students. Let us not cause their absence by loudness.
We are guests of the Hopkins' "Y." As such let us show our
appreciation and cooperate to the greatest extent.

NIGHT CONTEST
Gridiron Lighted By 44 1,000Watt Bulbs
Last Saturday night the Blue
Jays were crushingly defeated by
the strong Syracuse team, which
seemingly had no trouble in running
rough shod over their southern opponents and rolling up a tremendously large score. The game was
started at 8 P. B., and the field,
which was lighted by the strong
rays of forty-four 1,000-watt bulbs,
was as light as day. The previous
Saturday, Syracuse had fought the
strong western eleven from the University of Nebraska, the game being very close and both elevens
fighting like tigers. It was only
through sheer brute strength and
very hard fighting, that Nebraska
wa sable to triumph over their opponents, winning by the score of 13
to 6. This year Syracuse is playing
the majority of her games at night
under the powerful arc lights and
on her own gridiron.
New Practice

The practice of playing football
games at night is a new and experimental one. It is thought that
larger crowds can be drawn to the
stadiums for these games by having
them in the evenings. It is also
felt that many of those people who
have to work Saturday afternoons
and are necessairily kept from attending afternoon contests, would
be interested in night games and
would attend them.
New Experience

This game was the first one that
Hopkins had ever played at night
and naturally it was a novel experience for them. At first they were
not used to the glaring lights, but
they were soon able to acclimate
themselves to this new situation and
to eliminate the confusion into
which they had been thrown at the
beginning of the game.
Hopkins Outclassed

From the very start, it was easy
to see that Hopkins was outclassed
in every shape and form by the
strong, well-experienced Syracuse
eleven. Last year Syracuse had a
very powerful team and defeated
Hopkins by a large margin and the
team this year is made up of most
of the old regulars from last season. Naturally these husky men,
who had seen battle in more than
one season, were more than a match
for the crippled Jay team.
Hopkins Alert

Although the Jays were thoroughly outclassed, they nevertheless
showed the old Hopkins fighting
spirit and were alert and always on
the look-out for any breaks that
might come their way. They were
rewarded, in the first part of the
last quarter by a little streak of
luck, which netted them a touchdown.
Jays Score

The Orange team had started
another march down the field and
were sure of scoring. A long forward pass was attempted and Merriken, Hopkins' right halfback intercepted it and made a beautiful
run of 47 yards to place the ball
on Syracuse's 10-yard line. After
a forward pass had been grounded,
the ball was given to Bledsoe, who
carried it over for Hopkins' only
tally. The try for the extra point
failed and the Jays were forced to
content themselves with the one
touchdown.

OPKINS students are appreciative. One organization and one
achievement of that organization have especially received their
share of that appreciative attitude. We speak of Levering Hall, the
property of the University branch of the Y. M. C. A.
Levering Hall has opened wide its doors to every one affiliated with
Hopkins. It is appreciated. But the appreciation of the student seems
to be slowly but surely fading.
Since the opening of college, Hopkins students have made themselves
at home. It is undoubtedly proper and to be expected that this "at
home" attitude exists, providing no one passes the limit defined by that
comprehensive phrase. But some have passed.

H

Within the last several days we have noticed several tendencies
indicative of this condition. The combination radio and phonograph
does not operate. This seemed to be expected by many who have been
heard to say, "It did last pretty long, though." When the defect has
been repaired let us be content to enjoy it as an instrument and not
a toy.
The broken radio is not the only indication of the attitude we have
mentioned. Coats, hats, and books are to be seen nearly any hour of
the day, strewn over chair backs, tables, or windowsills. Lockers have
been distributed for the disposition of our garments and texts during
the hours of classes. During functions, we may check our coats at the
room set aside for that purpose. Thoughtlessly tossed articles do not
add to the appearance of the large lobby in Levering Hall.
Ashes are flicked to the floor, although ash trays have been furnished
in abundance throughout the several rooms. Even if a tray is not
within reach, a few steps would bring it so. Cigarette ashes are not
allowed to remain on the floor, due to excellent janitor service; but
certainly the sight of a student carelessly dropping ashes or the remnants of his "smoke" on the floor is not conducive to an appreciative

most deplored by authorities was the speech and loudness of those who
frequented the second floor of the Barn. Levering Hall is as much at
